context: The metal's distinctive natural <a0_0><b5_0>green<b5_0/><a0_0/> patina has long been coveted by architects and designers. The final patina is a particularly durable layer that is <a1_0><b6_0>highly resistant to atmospheric corrosion<b6_0/><a1_0/>, thereby protecting the underlying metal against further weathering. It can be a mixture of <a2_0><b7_0>carbonate and sulfate<b7_0/><a2_0/> compounds in various amounts, depending upon <a3_0><b8_0>environmental<b8_0/><a3_0/> conditions such as sulfur-containing acid rain. Architectural copper and its alloys can also be '<a4_0><b9_0>finished<b9_0/><a4_0/>' to embark a particular look, feel, and/or color. Finishes include mechanical surface treatments, chemical coloring, and coatings.
